Situation1: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: I was dressed in my finest kurta, the scent of sandalwood clinging to my skin as I hurried through the park, eager not to be late for my cousin’s puja. My mother’s words echoed in my mind: “Arrive early, show respect.” In my hand, I clutched a box of sweets, wrapped in shiny paper. As I walked, I unwrapped a piece, tossing the wrapper into the nearest bush, thinking only of the ceremony ahead. But then I saw the no-littering sign, bold and clear, and the trash bin just a few steps away. Guilt pricked at me—my duty as a citizen was to keep the park clean, to respect the rules that kept our city beautiful. Yet, the thought of being late, of disappointing my family and disrespecting the ritual, pressed heavily on me. I stood frozen, torn between the expectations of my faith and my responsibility to my community, the sweet still melting on my tongue as I wrestled with what to do next.
